messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 67 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: IBIA: An Incremental Build-Infer-Approximate Framework for Approximate Inference of Partition Function

Paper Abstract: Abstract Exact computation of the partition function is known to be intractable, necessitating approximate inference techniques. Existing methods for approximate inference are slow to converge for many benchmarks. The control of accuracy-complexity trade-off is also non-trivial in many of these methods. We propose a novel incremental build-infer-approximate (IBIA) framework for approximate inference that addresses these issues. In this framework, the probabilistic graphical model is converted into a sequence of clique tree forests (SCTF) with bounded clique sizes. We show that the SCTF can be used to efficiently compute the partition function. We propose two new algorithms which are used to construct the SCTF and prove the correctness of both. The first is an algorithm for incremental construction of CTFs that is guaranteed to give a valid CTF with bounded clique sizes and the second is an approximation algorithm that takes a calibrated CTF as input and yields a valid and calibrated CTF with reduced clique sizes as the output. We have evaluated our method using several benchmark sets from recent UAI competitions and our results show good accuracies with competitive runtimes.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 67 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 67"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "NeuroBE: Escalating neural network approximations of bucket elimination",
        "Partition function estimation: A quantitative study",
        "Bucket renormalization for approximate inference",
        "Thin junction trees",
        "Cascaded Bayesian inferencing for switching activity estimation with correlated inputs",
        "A modified simulation scheme for inference in Bayesian networks",
        "Tractable inference for complex stochastic processes",
        "Abstraction sampling in graphical models",
        "A scalable approximate model counter",
        "Algorithmic improvements in approximate counting for probabilistic inference: From linear to logarithmic sat calls",
        "On probabilistic inference by weighted model counting",
        "Ace version 3.0",
        "Approximating the partition function by deleting and then correcting for model edges",
        "Many pairs mutual information for adding structure to belief propagation approximations",
        "On Bayesian network approximation by edge deletion",
        "An edge deletion semantics for belief propagation and its practical impact on approximation quality",
        "Dynamic jointrees",
        "Clustering without (thinking about) triangulation",
        "Learning bounded treewidth Bayesian networks",
        "Incremental compilation of Bayesian networks",
        "Incremental region selection for mini-bucket elimination bounds",
        "Gibbs sampling",
        "IJGP-sampling and samplesearch (PR and MAR tasks)",
        "A complete anytime algorithm for treewidth",
        "Samplesearch: A scheme that searches for consistent samples",
        "Samplesearch: Importance sampling in presence of determinism",
        "A Monte Carlo algorithm for probabilistic propagation in belief networks based on importance sampling and stratified simulation techniques",
        "Convexity arguments for efficient minimization of the Bethe and Kikuchi free energies",
        "Approximate inference and constrained optimization",
        "UAI model files and solutions",
        "Pushing the power of stochastic greedy ordering schemes for inference in graphical models",
        "Scaling up and/or abstraction sampling",
        "Probabilistic graphical models: Principles and techniques",
        "Local computations with probabilities on graphical structures and their application to expert systems",
        "A weighted mini-bucket bound for solving influence diagram",
        "An extended depth-first search algorithm for optimal triangulation of Bayesian networks",
        "Improved high dimensional discrete Bayesian network inference using triplet region construction",
        "Bounding the partition function using holderâ€™s inequality",
        "Probabilistic variational bounds for graphical models",
        "Dynamic importance sampling for anytime bounds of the partition function",
        "Interleave variational optimization with Monte Carlo sampling: A tale of two approximate inference paradigms",
        "Join-graph propagation algorithms",
        "Expectation propagation for approximate Bayesian inference",
        "Power ep",
        "libDAI: A free and open source C++ library for discrete approximate inference in graphical models",
        "Loop corrections for approximate inference on factor graphs",
        "Dynamic importance sampling in Bayesian networks based on probability trees",
        "Loopy belief propagation for approximate inference: An empirical study",
        "Dynamic Bayesian networks: Representation, inference and learning, dissertation",
        "The probabilistic inference challenge (pic2011)",
        "Deep bucket elimination",
        "On the hardness of approximate reasoning",
        "Approximate structure learning for large Bayesian networks",
        "GANAK: A scalable probabilistic exact model counter",
        "Tightening LP relaxations for MAP using message passing",
        "BIRD: Engineering an efficient cnf-xor sat solver and its applications to approximate model counting",
        "The 2010 UAI Approximate inference challenge",
        "UAI 2014 - Probabilistic inference competition",
        "UAI 2022 - Competition",
        "Expectation propagation as a way of life: A framework for Bayesian inference on partitioned data",
        "Tree-based reparameterization for approximate inference on loopy graphs",
        "Fractional belief propagation",
        "Variational message passing",
        "On the role of multiply sectioned Bayesian networks to cooperative multiagent systems",
        "Multiply sectioned Bayesian networks and junction forests for large knowledge-based systems",
        "Generalized belief propagation",
        "Exploiting causal independence in Bayesian network inference"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 67 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in IBIA: An Incremental Build-Infer-Approximate Framework for Approximate Inference of Partition Function, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
